topics.body:
"@Virgil Stormblade":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2ebf8636872571c000bc3#post_55b2ebf8636872571c000bc3

Until prove otherwise, time travel is theoretical and is guided by Murphy's Law: If it has the probability of happening in any and all forms no matter how tiny, it will.
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2ec2b63687278930000a0#post_55b2ec2b63687278930000a0
Correction: more than likely with our current understanding of physics time travel isn't possible.  It's like faster than light travel; even though science fiction likes talking about these tropes a lot as far as we know so far it's impossible.


The reasons why both of these aren't possible as far as we can tell so far is that creating portals or such to a different time or place runs the risk of creating a exotic particles; exotic particles run the risk in large quantities of pretty much metaphorically you're fucked.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2ecad636872773800013a#post_55b2ecad636872773800013a

_Au contraire_. Faster than light travel is possible in theory. Particles with mass can never reach the speed of light, +however+, there's no law that space itself cannot exceed c, so instead of trying to accelerate the object past the speed of light, you move space itself around the object, mathematically this requires a negative energy density, which in turn requires the generation of lots and lots of exotic matter with negative mass, but this would mean you go from "You'll need Universal levels of energy", to "Jupiter size levels of energy".
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4

topics.body: forward time travel is possible, look up time dilation
topics.author: 37e5b9d66361642500af5e00

You need to be close to a black hole for that to happen. And if you're that close, chances are it's not going to be pretty

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2edce6368724eb000074d#post_55b2edce6368724eb000074d
The problem with that theory is the "tearing" problem.  If you travel faster than light you run the risk of literally ripping apart matter.

A while back they were testing whether or not the rate at which the universe is expanding will accelerate and as a result cause reality to essentially rip apart almost instantly meaning at any point he universe could literally rip apart, fortunately the rate at which the universe is expanding won't reach that point of acceleration.

Basically warp speed would rip you to shreds.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

there are two types. Dilation due to velocity and dilation due to gravity

topics.body:
"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2ef266368724e59000140#post_55b2ef266368724e59000140
It's not true "time travel" but rather time for you slowing down in comparison to the rest of the universe.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2ef9c6368724e590001b9#post_55b2ef9c6368724e590001b9
It doesn't have to do with getting used to it; rather atoms can't maintain their integrity.  It's like filing a balloon with water; you can't infinitely put water in it cause eventually the balloon will lose structural integrity.

"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2f10163687214650000cb#post_55b2f10163687214650000cb
The problem with that is you run the risk of creating a subspace bubble; ie you're definitely fucked cause you would never be able to interact with the rest of the universe cause you've effectively cut yourself off completely from the known universe.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body: Ok, Ignoring any gravitational time dilation due to the earth; T ~0~ is called the proper time, for the sake of this we will make it 1 second so it would be 1 second per second. Okok now the formula for time dilation due to velocity is  !https://sciencebasedlife.files.wordpress.com/2012/08/time-dilation-3.jpg! now we'll use the space station's velocity as v. which is 7660 m/s and c is 299792458 m/s. now due the math it's easy. 7660 ^2^ divided by 299792458 ^2^ is .0000000006 1 minus that is about .9999999994  square root that .999999997 divide by 1 so the time the passangeers on the space station compared to an outside observer with a time proper of 1 is about 1.0000000003 slower
topics.author: 37e5b9d66361642500af5e00

topics.body: so what im saying is 1.0000000003 seconds is one second for a passenger on the space station not counting any gravitational dilation
topics.author: 37e5b9d66361642500af5e00

Which means that if you found a way to cut off a person from an XYZ bubble means they can be brought back via reverse experimenting. You found a way to make Einstenian particles interact with another Universe which means travel between dimensions would become factible at some point.

topics.body:
"@Kaz":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2f2d0636872772e000985#post_55b2f2d0636872772e000985
We know what time dilation is; I'm talking not about time dilation but time travel as in back to the future time travel.  As far as physicists know so far time *travel* not dilation is impossible.

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2f2d963687278930008a8#post_55b2f2d963687278930008a8
[bq="QuasarNova"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2f17b63687278930006a2#post_55b2f17b63687278930006a2

Which means that if you found a way to cut off a person from an XYZ bubble means they can be brought back via reverse experimenting. You found a way to make Einstenian particles interact with another Universe which means travel between dimensions would become factible at some point.[/bq]
The problem is that chances are the subspace bubble would reach heat death extremely fast.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2f3696368727893000978#post_55b2f3696368727893000978

You said it yourself: "Chances are". So there's an equal number of possibilities that the bubble would not even move from their initial position and only appear to be moving.
topics.author: 4fdfbf92945b7075d50036e4

topics.body:
"@QuasarNova":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/55b2f3fd636872772e000b70#post_55b2f3fd636872772e000b70
Problems with time travel:
1)Exotic particles
2)"Ripping"
3)Subspace bubbles
4)Accelerated heat death inside the subspace bubble
5)There would be no way of getting back into your original universe
6)Accelerated spacial expansion

Essentially if you time traveled you would be destroyed in every possible way and even in some impossible ways.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600
